physical_examinations.relevant_findings: Visual acuity was 20/800 in the right eye and 20/25 in the fellow eye. External eye and anterior segment examination were normal in both eyes. Ophthalmoscopic examination of the right eye depicted innumerable, small, elongated basal laminar drusen in a radial pattern, submacular fibrous tissue, hyperplasia of the RPE affecting the fovea, and peripapillary drusen. The left eye had radial drusen in a similar distribution, submacular fibrous tissue, scattered RPE hyperplasia, and peripapillary drusen.
physical_examinations.changes_over_time: Visual acuity improved from 20/800 to 20/40 three weeks post-treatment, then decreased to 20/50 nine weeks after PDT, and remained stable at 20/60 thirty-four weeks after PDT.

physical_examinations.relevant_findings: Visual acuity was 20/25 in the left eye, and a fluorescein angiogram did not reveal distinct choroidal neovascularization (CNV) or leakage.
physical_examinations.changes_over_time: Visual acuity decreased to 20/60 two months later, and clinical evidence of subretinal fluid was detected.

physical_examinations.relevant_findings: Visual acuity decreased slightly to 20/50, with a small area of shallow subretinal fluid clinically detected, and a fluorescein angiogram showed a microscopic hyperfluorescent spot at the site of the previously active CNV.
physical_examinations.changes_over_time: Visual acuity subsequently remained stable at 20/60 after thirty-four weeks, with no significant changes in clinical manifestation or fluorescein angiogram study.

physical_examinations.relevant_findings: Visual acuity remained 20/60 in the left eye, and fluorescein angiography demonstrated resolution of the subretinal fluid and no signs of active leakage from the CNV.
